Freefall under gravity is a constant acceleration yes, but if you arent in a vacuum, then objects that have larger surface area (in the direction of falling) per mass will be affected more by air resistance, which acts as a deceleration, reducing the resultant acceleration for that object. This is why a feather will fall slower, because the wind and air resistance throw it about because it is light, and has a large SA:mass ratio. So 'the same time' is only correct in a simplified model.

Mass is the amount of "stuff" something has. Gravity is the attraction between 2 bodies with mass. WEIGHT is the force exerted on a body with mass by a gravitational field. Nothing travels faster than light. The speed of light (3*10^8 m/s) is the universal speed limit.  Imagine the universe as a spread out sheet and the black hole as a very dense and heavy ball. You can imagine that since the ball is so heavy, it 'bends' the sheet. This is perceptually what a black hole does. It's mass is so dense it 'bends' or warps space-time. Now imagine light as photons or packets of energy or in our example, small marbles. Contd. in next comment.

Acceleration is the change of velocity over time. When you are about to jump from a cliff, your vertical velocity is 0 (i.e. you're not moving down or up). When you jump in that first second, your initial velocity is 0. By the first second you would have reached a velocity of 9.8m/s. As Liam Neeson mentioned above, acceleration in this case is constant so the only other changing variable is time. So initially you start slow but over time your change of velocity would be significant.

Set this to equal the time it takes for the object to fall,

y/v = v/g

Multiply both sides by the velocity, v, to get,

y = v²/g

Put in Bolt's speed for v (10.27 m/s), square it, and then divide by g (9.8 m/s²) and you get the distance Usain Bolt can run and finish at exactly the same time the object hits the ground. The distance you get is 10,76 meters.

(PART 1)We can easily calculate the longest distance Usain Bolt can run at the same time it takes for an object to fall that same distance. Usain Bolt runs at a velocity of ~ 37 km/h = 10.27 m/s. The downward velocity of an object in free fall after t seconds is,

v = gt

Where g is the gravitational acceleration (~ 9.8 m/s²). To get the time it takes for the object to reach the same speed as Bolt, we have,

t = v/g 

And Usain Bolt runs at a speed,

v = y/t

(y is distance),
But if one person jumped higher than another and they finished at the same time the one who jumped higher went a further distance in the same time and therefore went faster.
